title: Algebraic number
summary: An algebraic number is a number that is a root of a non-zero polynomial in one variable with integer (or equivalently, rational) coefficients.  For example, the golden ratio, ( 1 + 5 ) / 2 {\displaystyle (1+{\sqrt {5}})/2} , is an algebraic number, because it is a root of the polynomial x2 - x - 1. That is, it is a value for x for which the polynomial evaluates to zero.  As another example, the complex number 1 + i {\displaystyle 1+i} is algebraic because it is a root of x4 + 4.
